Recommended Changes to Improve Safety:

Recommendations were developed during the 2022 technical studies (i.e., PHA and seismic studies).  These recommendations will be studied and will be closed in a timely manner.

e located in the vicinity of the ammonia storage tank, cupric oxide reactor, the maintenance shop, the laboratory, and on the north side of the facility, along the fence line (2).  The ammonia sensors are located outside and therefore are protected with a porous plastic cover to prevent contact with chemicals, dirt, water, or dust contaminants. 

Emergency Shut Down Buttons

Ammonia remote emergency shutdown (ESD) buttons are placed throughout the facility.  In the event of an emergency, the operator can use one of these buttons to shut off the ammonia flow.  The five (5) ammonia ESD buttons are located: near the ammonia etchant area, the maintenance shop, the production office (2), and the transportation coordinator's office.

Chemical Storage Dike Areas

All of the chemical recovery process equipment and acid storage vessels are located in diked areas at different locations throughout the facility.  There is no containment around the anhydrous ammonia storage tank.

Maintenance Programs

Operational and preventative maintenance programs are in place to maintain the mechanical integrity of the ammonia ammonia processes at the facility to ensure workplace and off-site receptor safety.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Phibro-Tech facility has not had an accidental release of ammonia in the past five years.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Phibro-Tech has an emergency plan in effect at the facility. The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year to ensure compliance with the applicable regulations, as well as to incorporate facility changes.

Process Hazards Analysis 

A five-year PHA update was conducted by March 25, 2022.  No significant changes to the ammonia processes have occurred in the la

ial areas to the west and northwest.

The regulated substance of concern at Phibro-Tech is ammonia.  The process that uses the regulated substance is the Aqueous Ammonia Etchant System.  

Aqueous Ammonia Etchant System:

The facility stores a maximum of 58,000 pounds (10,200 gallons) of anhydrous ammonia in the bulk anhydrous ammonia tank. The facility also stores etchant product solution that is an aqueous solution of ammonia (concentration is less than 20 percent). ns. 

Anhydrous ammonia, water, carbon dioxide (CO2), and other additives are combined with ammonium chloride solutions in mix tanks (reactor vessels) to produce product (etchant). The process is a batch process. The ammonium chloride solutions are produced in the cupric chloride and copper ammonium chloride systems elsewhere in the facility. The product solutions created in the mix tanks are transferred to storage tanks for holding. These solutions are then transferred to drum, totes and tankers for shipment to customers. Prior to filling, all drums and totes are washed to remove the remains of prior etchant solutions. A scrubbing system removes ammonia vapors from the exhaust of all process vents. A system of ammonia sensors is in the process area and at strategic locations along the fence line to detect accidental releases of ammonia. A process logic controller, in conjunction with various sensors, interlocks, and the electronically controlled anhydrous ammonia valves, ensures safe operation of the process.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The Phibro-Tech facility, including each chemical recovery system, was designed and constructed in accordance with the Uniform Mechanical Code, which specifically outlines requirements for the safe operation of chemical recovery systems. These safety features include ammonia sensors, automatic shutdown buttons, and scrubbers, each of which is described below.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY


This Executive Summary summarizes Phibro-Tech, Inc.'s administrative and operational programs to prevent ammonia-related accidents and reduce potential risks.  The regulated substance of concern and focus of this executive summary is ammonia.  The following topics are addressed in this Executive Summary:

- Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies,
- Stationary Source and Regulated Substance,
- Off-site Consequence Analysis,
- Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps,
- Five-Year Accident History,
- Emergency Response Program, and
- Planned Changes to Improve Safety.


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The Phibro-Tech facility abides by the emergency procedures and policies detailed in the Emergency Action Plan manual.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:

1.)	To save lives.
2.)	To minimize and avoid injuries.
3.)	To protect the environment.
4.)	To minimize property damage.

Phibro-Tech maintains an emergency response committee whose members are the designated emergency coordinators for the facility. The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, anhydrous and aqueous ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility. This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year. 

The anhydrous ammonia process at Phibro-Tech is a Program Level 3 process under PSM, RMP, and California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP). 

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Phibro-Tech facility is located at 8851 Dice Road in Santa Fe Springs, California.  The facility is located approximately 1.8 kilometers (1.1 miles) east of the 605 Freeway and 0.6 kilometers (0.4 miles) south of Slauson Avenue.
